I apologize for the ads and banners on the videos, but that is how videos I make are monetized. I'm not sure how the algorithm works, but I think clicks on the ads plays a part. Hey Destin, I love all your videos. They're educational and inspiring.
I read about a research studying the aerodynamics of hummingbird:
1. Setup an apparatus to lure the hummingbird
2. Spray the airfield with atomized olive oil particles
3. Laser the field for visualization
4. Capture photos to study the airflow, circulation, vortices, etc
I was thinking that maybe you can do something similar too!
Reference: Aerodynamics of Hovering Hummingbird - Warrick, Tobalske, Powers (2005)
Thanks Destin.  Because of you, now I'm going to Tambopata Research Center with my wife.  And I WILL bring my macro.

No your pretty close, Almost all flying animals and insects do this. What they are doing is changing the shape of the wing on the up stroke and again on the down stroke. Depending on the shape, they can change the aerodynamics in the vertical plane as well as the horizontal. Also, many flying insects and birds can achieve lift on both the upstroke and down stroke by warping the wings and twisting their body.

Im not an expert on this either but if you look closely at how the butterfly flaps its wings down and up, you can see that it is not just a straight up and straight down motion. If you look at the video closely when the butterfly flaps "upward", it turns the wings in such a way that it doesnt actually push "up" making itself go down but instead pushes "back" making the body move forward and thus making it able to go up AND forward. but then again that is just how i see it. i might be wrong!
